Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assembling the Echinoderm Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Echinoderms include familiar animals such as starfishes, sea urchins, and a wide array of extinct forms stretching back to the Cambrian Period, circa 500 million years ago. Echinoderms share a common ancestor with backboned animals and thus provide a crucial link to understanding a huge portion of the entire tree of life as well as the history of our species. This project, the Echinoderm Tree of Life Project, will resolve the phylogenetic placement of Echinoderms within the tree of life and clarify important unresolved relationships among major echinoderm lineages using data from genetic sequencing and anatomy.

Echinoderms are fascinating, and their unique features, such as mutable ligaments and novel means of detecting light, have biomedical engineering applications. Because research on such marine animals and their adaptations is naturally attractive to young people, excellent students are expected to be recruited and the importance of science will be communicated to a broad audience. Long-term impacts, embodied by scientific publications, textbooks, anatomical and genomic data, and extensive pages in the Tree of Life and Encyclopedia of Life web projects, will provide resources to researchers and educators. Outreach will include videos and broadcasts about marine exploration and applications of fundamental biological research across the biomedical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The class Asteroidea (starfish or sea stars) are an ancient group within the phylum Echinodermata (the ‘spiny-skinned animals,’ including sea urchins, feather stars and sea cucumbers), having diverged about 500 million years ago. The group is also rich in the number of extant [living] species, containing roughly 2000 extant species grouped into 7 orders, approximately 40 families and about 300 genera. As with other echinoderms, asteroids are exclusively marine, and occur at all ocean depths from shallow water to the deep sea. Asteroids are present in all of the world’s oceans, but have the highest species diversity in the tropical Atlantic and Indo-Pacific regions. Asteroids are important for research in several areas, including ecology, developmental biology, genetics, immunology, physiology, biochemistry and parasitology. Asteroids are also frequently depicted in popular culture--for example, Patrick Star [a cartoon character in the television series SpongeBob SquarePants]--yet fundamental information regarding their biology and evolution is often lacking.

My collaborators and I wanted to resolve the early diversification events in the evolutionary history of this class of echinoderms, which have remained controversial for about a century. We also wanted in particular to resolve phylogenetic relationships for the enigmatic echinoderm Xyloplax, a small disc-shaped echinoderm that was discovered in the 1980s on sunken wood in the deep sea off the Bahamas and New Zealand. The evolutionary relationships of Xyloplax have been controversial since its initial discovery.

To address these questions, my collaborators and I developed and used a new computer-based method to analyze a large amount of RNA sequence data that were collected for this project at Duke University. We analyzed many asteroid species and gene regions, including 21 species sampled from all living asteroid orders and 13 families, plus four brittlestar species as an outgroup (brittlestars are the closest living relatives to asteroids). To expand the coverage, we added six previously published asteroid sequence datasets.

Our methods recovered 19 evolutionary trees, all of which reconstructed Xyloplax as a member of the order Velatida. We also found that most conventional orders or superorders of living asteroids were monophyletic.

The RNA sequence data, translated into amino acid sequences, have been made available to other researchers in a publicly-accessible, searchable database called EchinoDB. The number of different amino acid sequences per asteroid pecies ranges from 312 to 47,492. These data can be used for further research in developmental biology, gene family studies, neuroscience and other areas of comparative biology.
